div.head: Typology (Local)
div.p: The Jewish dialects of Yemen were similar to Muslim ethnolects in the countryside, whereas in the cities, there were distinct Jewish ethnolects. Many speakers are L1 Hebrew speakers today.

div.head: General
div.p: Yemeni Jews today live in Israel, the USA, and elsewhere in the world. Only between 100-300 still remained in Yemen in the early 2000s, according to estimates, and there are virtually none today.

Yemeni immigration to what today is Israel began in the 1880ies. This was religiously and economically motivated and facilitated by the ability to travel freely within the Ottoman Empire. At that time, the Yemeni Jews were an organic part of Yemeni society.

During the British mandate of Palestine, immigration certificates were given out only in limited numbers by the British authorities. When the atrocities of the Holocaust became known, the Zionist entity in secret operations sought to bring Jews from all over the world to Palestine to increase the Jewish presence. However, after the end of the Second World War, Holocaust survivors were prioritised in receiving immigration certificates and Yemeni immigration halted.

The numbers of people waiting under dire conditions in camps in and around Aden, then a British protectorate, overwhelmed the British authorities. They tried to encourage the people to stay in Yemen, especially since many of them did not have the wealth or vocational training required to make a living unassisted by welfare measures.

After the foundation of the state of Israel in 1948, the limitations on Jewish immigration fell. By then, the Jewish community in Yemen had come under pressure as their formerly good relations with their Muslim neighbours deteriorated, and about 80 of them had been killed in a massacre in 1947 in Aden. Almost 50,000 Yemeni Jews were brought to Israel on planes in what was dubbed “Operation on Wings of Eagles” or “Operation Magic Carpet”.

Yemeni Jews did not undergo secularisation before coming to Israel. To this day they are sometimes faced with orientalist views. For a long time, they were largely excluded from positions of leadership, and they are generally still poorer than Ashkenazi Jews. Recognition for their culture and approval of their language, however, has increased in recent years.

div.head: Research history
div.p: The vernacular of Yemenite Jews has been studied exclusively in Yemenite communities in Israel. Naturally, the dialects differ from each other as Yemen has a diverse dialect landscape. There were significant Jewish populations in cities such as Sanʿa and Saʿda as well as in rural tribal areas.

Interest in the Yemenite Jews has been great, especially on the part of Israeli Jewish scholars. The view on them has been somewhat ambivalent: The Yemenis were seen as the preservers of an original and pure “Jewishness”, but also as “oriental” and “backward”.

Two volumes published by Goitein in 1932 and 1934 (in German) on Yemeni folk tales are among the earliest studies undertaken in Israel. Goitein 1960 studied the language of the al-Gades village in lower Yemen. A valuable contribution to the knowledge of lexicon and popular proverbs and sayings is Goitein 1970.
Diem 1973 describes Jewish and other Yemenite dialects. Piamenta’s dictionary of 1991-1992 in two volumes reflects both Judeo-Yemeni characteristics and other Yemeni colloquials.
Studies undertaken in Hebrew on Yemenite Arabic are Kara 1986 and Tobi 1986, among others.
Shachmon’s 2007 PhD dissertation (in Hebrew) as well as several articles such as Shachmon 2015, 2017 and 2020 investigate the Yemeni Jewish vernacular.
Geva-Kleinberger 2016 is an article on the wedding songs of a community from Ḥabbān in eastern Yemen that has preserved unique traditions. It also provides the lyrics of the songs in transcription.
Since 1989, the Tema: Journal for Judeo-Yemenite Studies is published in Hebrew.

There have been ample studies of the Hebrew and Aramaic components in the speech of Yemenite Jews, see for example Goitein 1931 (in Hebrew), Morag 2002 and Shachmon 2013. There are also many works on Judeo-Yemeni songs and poetry, see for example Wagner 2008.

div.head: Dictionaries
div.p: A dictionary of Yemeni Arabic, partly collected in Israel is Piamenta 1991-1992.
